segments.text: But somebody needs to.

Well, there is some activity going, I think, on the history of OMR, perhaps right this year, because this is their 30th anniversary, and they're asking people to write articles, and I wouldn't be surprised at what they have.
A historian somewhere who's worrying about this.
Well, I think that certainly...
in the period just after World War II, there's no question, but the Navy built oceanography.
It really had, at least in the United States.
And I think one thing, well, there just had been no deep water oceanography in the United States before World War II.
And on the other hand, after World War II, it grew very, very fast, and it grew because
Well, there were two kinds of contributions to the Navy, three kinds of contributions to the Navy.
One was the obvious one of providing dollars for research.
There was a second one, which was that there were a lot of people who, one way or another, had become interested in the ocean during World War II by being naval officers.
And in fact, if you look around, you'll find a fair fraction of the people of my generation in oceanography who were indeed naval officers or
somehow or other got involved in either that or were involved in naval research during World War II.
It was just a time when there was a lot going on.
The third thing that happened was that the Navy had built a lot of ships during World War II.
They didn't need them when the war was over.
And so there were a number of institutions that were able to put their hands on floating facilities in the period of the 50s.
that they never would have, that just plain never would have existed if it hadn't been for the naval buildup during World War II and its subsequent decline after World War II.
We had Navy tugs and things like this that we operated as our key research ships in the early days of the institution.

In fact, up until, well, this went on long enough that the Navy began to feel that it had a responsibility for providing research ships and went ahead and started building a whole class of research ships
And of the ships that Scripps operates right now, a fair number of them, all the biggest ones, are hulls that were provided by the Navy.
Navy doesn't fund the operation in any sense.
We have to justify the operational funding on the basis of research programs.
And some of those research programs are Navy programs, some are National Science Foundation.
But the ships are made available to us

without any, you know, paying rent or anything of this kind, they're just plain bailed to the institutions, largely on the grounds that the programs are indeed federal programs and too considerable to say they aren't.
And I think that the, this, this is a fairly important kind of thing.
It's given our Navy a really strong base in the scientific world and the capability to
to do things and to call on people for advisory help and to have a good base of understanding of the ocean probably couldn't have existed in any other way.
Really, you look at the different populations in the United States, the fisheries people, the manganese module people, the oil people, whatever, and you see that, at least I think,
that if you look at the deep ocean, the major consumer of information about the deep ocean is the United States Navy.
And that so that they have a vested interest in seeing that there is good work done.
But I think that people who work in the sea also have a kind of vested interest in seeing that the Navy operates in an intelligent manner and so have an obligation in return to
conceive good research things and to be sure that they are well understood once they're finished.
The ONR has, of course, become more mission-oriented rather than research-oriented in the very recent past, actually.
Yeah, I guess that may be one way of saying it.
I think I would look at it in a little different way.
I think what has happened is that science has grown
Fantastically.
The Office of Naval Research budget has not grown in pace with this.
I don't think that ONR in its major oceanographic program has necessarily become any more applied.
It's that the field has gotten so big, the options have gotten so big, and their budget has not increased in proportion.
So they've had to say, all right, what are the things we're going to fund?

And so out of the range of scientific endeavors that they could pursue in the sea, they have naturally, since they can't do everything, they've picked up the ones that seem to them to have the most relevance to nature.
There's been a lot of talk about relevance and there was a manuscript amendment game that I felt was used by a lot of people to cut research budgets rather than
to improve relevance.
If you said, well, basic research is not relevant, then you could cut almost anything.
On the other hand, there's hardly anything you can study in the ocean that isn't in some way, a knowledgeable person can show that it's in some way relevant to the Navy.
The question of cutting down oceanographic research on the grounds of lack of relevance is pretty hard to justify.

And in fact, if you look at what happened to O&R during a period in which that was really going up, it squeezed its programs, but it squeezed the non-ocean programs a great deal harder than it did the ocean programs.
like a third of our budget at this point, whereas in other years there was a lot of nuclear physics and things of this sort.
And basically I think the decision was that the Navy would fund fairly heavily in basic research areas in which no other mission-oriented agency in federal government had much at stake.
And so, this pretty much says that other people who fund, the earlier people who funded nuclear things and uses nuclear power won't put much money into basic research in that category.
They'll put a lot into oceanography because there aren't many other agencies that have the radios.
Do you think that the funding ONR did
earlier when it just simply gave lump sums to institutions to be sort of parceled out to researchers?
Do you think it was more creative then than it is now when it asked for specific proposals?
Yes.
Well, what's happened over the years is that as we've moved from these sort of block funding things into more and more narrowly defined projects, on the one hand, you find that you
The amount of paperwork that you have to do for a research dollar these days has gone up in probably a factor of 10 in the last 15 years.
It's way, way up.
The other result of what is primarily the result of just plain projectizing everything and cutting it down into smaller and smaller pieces, it's around now where
In the National Science Foundation, for example, the average size of grant in oceanography has not gone up in the last half dozen years, in spite of the fact that inflation has gone up.
And it's clear that to get a given amount of work done, it costs more money.
What this means is that people are dividing their work up into smaller and smaller pieces.
And this means that the money is compartmentalized, and you have to plan the spending
on each individual little project to within a tenth of a percent.
Whereas in other times, I think people may be under some misapprehension with regard to this block funding sort of business.
There was always a program presented, and certain investigators were clearly going to be supported.
It was not just a sort of chunk of money that disappeared into the director's office and came out the other end according to his whim.
He had to present a program.
The big advantage was that

you were sort of morally bound to put the money pretty much the way it went, but this was sort of to within 90% instead of 99%, and that meant that if somebody within your organization had misjudged his budgetary requirements, usually there were about as many people who misjudged high as low, and you could
move the money around and compensate for this, and everybody could get his work done on the way up to the hill, and the money would be spent in the most fruitful manner possible.
I think that money is not spent as fruitfully when it is divided into little tiny packages.
What about ONR and NSL, in effect, encouraging and creating departments of oceanography?
Do you think this was essentially a good thing?
And I don't know.

Up to a point it certainly was a good thing because oceanography had grown and there was no reason that it should grow only in the places where there had been oceanography in 1948 or something like that.
So in that sense, there's no... it should have been done.
It had to be done.
Certainly if you took the three or four big places and said that they were going to be now involved in oceanography by all the academic oceanography, they'd be considerably bigger than they are.
It's not clear that the world would be better off without them.
There was room for more.
I think there was sort of an overdoing of this, and we're seeing that now, and I think it's kind of retrenched.
groups are kind of withering and dying.

I think that there was no way to know what the optimum would be, and so there was an expansion which became an over-expansion, which now is turning into a contraction, which I hope won't become an over-contraction.

Well, in terms of naval stimulation of these departments, do you think possibly scientific research is suffering now because of the necessity of ONR in divining its funds up to a multiplicity of departments rather than a few institutions?
I don't know.

I think that ONR, I can't speak for ONR, of course, but I think that they are gradually adjusting themselves to the idea that they can't support a large number of places and that there is a certain kind of

you have to have a certain dimension before you can operate a ship effectively and things of this kind and that it probably is best to have oceanography done in a fairly modest number of fairly good sized places rather than supporting work.
I think this happens naturally to some extent in that the people who are in

disadvantaged institutions, institutions that are just plain can't quite get up to the threshold, they can't do as good work and so they don't fare as well when proposals are reviewed because they don't have the facilities and they don't have the... Another part of the game is the strong interaction with other people.
I've been invited by a variety of places to leave here and go off and take a job, be director of this or professor there or something.
And every time I've searched my soul and stayed here, and one of the major reasons I've stayed here has been that there are people here that I can talk to who are of a caliber that I can't
find in this kind of quantity if I go off to some other place.
And I enjoy that.
I think it helps me to do better research.
So that's a part of having a big enough place.
A lot of people think Scripps has got to be too big.
I guess I haven't heard of anybody who really left because of that reason.
In fact, most people who are here, even the ones who say it's too big,
would really like to have one more post-doctoral fellow, maybe a couple more graduate students, maybe an electronics technician, and so on.
There seems always to go that way.
Now that the research facilities, let's say, are divided up between NSF and ONR, do you see several projects which emerge which somehow seem to fit neither NSF nor ONR standards, and thus
fall between the cracks of the floor funding, if I may use that better?
I don't know.
I don't really recognize any major problems in this regard.
I think that people do...
There is a changing pattern in the sense that people are...
There are other agencies coming in to work in the ocean, particularly the near shore part of the ocean.
And some of them

want information about the ocean and people in the institutions are willing or interested in providing that information in return for the chance to get out to sea and learn some things that they would like to know for their own research.
By and large these other agencies are not as skilled for
that working with research people, as the old scenario of search has been historically, as NSF, was reasonable.
So groups like IRDA and Bureau of Land Management and so forth find that the scientific community finds it a little difficult to do things truthfully with them.
I think, and the fault is probably on both sides of the ledger in the sense that
And one thing you do have to recognize is that places like in Airplane Management or whatever have only kind of a transient interest in the ocean.
They want to find out about the strip that's right along the coast.

And once they have that, and while there is a lot to be learned there, they don't feel in the same sense that the Navy does or that people who charge demand set up with fostering mission are to be, that the ocean is something that is their primary
scientific object of interest.

There seems traditionally ONR and NSF and well now even the National Academy of Science have drawn the people who gave them guidance, allow me to say, from oceanography, sort of moving the civilians into these administrative posts.
Do you think that's good for the military to do that?
I'm not sure exactly what you're talking about.
Ned Estenzo, Richard Vedder, Finna Jennings.
Yeah, but you say it's good for the military to do that.
I'm not sure which way we're thinking of the migration as taking place.
A lot of the people, some people are people who were in the Navy establishment, so there is a need out of it.
off into NSF and other places.
If you look around Washington in the oceanographic administrative business, you'll find out that half of the leading administrators did their first administrative work in government in ONR.
Gordon Lill, over in the National Ocean Survey as part of NOAA, was one of the leaders in the geophysics branch of ONR way back in the early 50s.
Fina Jennings was one step after.
I mean, two in charge of that part, Maxwell was her, and then Lil, Maxwell, Jennings, and that part is going on.
And Jennings, of course, is the IDOU, and they're just, the place is shotgun.
They're in both NSF and NOAA.
I think that I enjoy, in the Navy research business, interacting to some extent with the naval officers as well as with the civilian scientists.
They take a completely different viewpoint, and there are times when I appreciate a pragmatic
viewpoint and applied viewpoint on some problems, perhaps more than some of my colleagues do.
I find it's fun sometimes to try to cope with a problem on the ocean or something like that.
Test my ingenuity.
There's been a great deal of pressure.
Let me begin by asking you a loaded question.
There's been a great deal of pressure in the 60s on the part of young scientists in cooperation with the military.
Now, I really can't say, you know, 60% of the scientists... Pressure against.
Pressure, but I mean pressure on institutions not to be as cooperative with the military.
That's right.
Did you, as a scientist coming from the military, ever feel this kind of uneasiness in terms of cooperation with the military?
No, I haven't felt any uneasiness.
I guess that's partly because of the situation in which I found myself in that...
I guess I sort of went at it with a missionary viewpoint.

I figured that I had enough independence sitting in the University of California to, and enough audacity, perhaps, to think that I could influence the military to do things in a more sensible way in the areas in which I understood.
And so, and I think that's been true of some of the others who have played this game and have done it,
We were really helping to keep the military from getting
in worse trouble than they would have gotten into, or something like this.
I have a lot of respect for a lot of the Navy people.
I've had practically no contact with Army and Air Force-type people.
And there are a lot of Navy people from whom I have a great deal of respect and have worked, and I think have worked very fruitfully.
And I think it's been kind of unfortunate that that move in the late 60s
Vietnam War and the rest of it and all the other things, I think it was strongly the Vietnam War that made it take that form.

But I think that's been bad for the country in the sense that their sort of division sprang up in that the scientists who were young in those days developed a standoffish attitude toward the military, which in the long run has meant that they don't have enough perspective
to see what some of the problems are that are relevant in the ocean.
At the same time, it developed on the part of the military people a reaction that said, well, what the hell with you?
And what that has led to is the growth of the in-house Navy laboratories to quite substantial size, much bigger than they had been before.
And those laboratories serve their function, they get things done toward naming, but they don't provide much of a back-door kind of aspect, which is what the academic community can provide.
If you know enough about the problem and feel some responsibility for helping to solve it in a rational way, you can
have a little less compunction about pointing out when they think the other color is doing it the wrong way.
People in the Navy laboratory have very little time seeing how to do that.

There also have been complaints rising in the scientific community about the interaction of oceanographers in particular with private enterprise as consultants and so forth on the grounds of obviously the ecology and the oceans.
Have you ever felt any uneasiness about this sort of association?
Well, I don't know.
Not really.
I haven't had any of that sort of association, particularly myself.
I can't think of any really good examples of people I have professional respect for.
running into any trouble in this recruitment.
There are a lot of marginal relation archivers who write environmental impact statements and they do them the best they can.
And I don't feel that they're necessarily being pushed or pulled in the right way.
They're just doing their job.
And sometimes, in fact, I suppose you've got to expect that an environmental impact statement may come out in such a way as to favor the developer.
There's this sort of possibility.
I think
That's not the thing I thought to be particularly bothersome.
I've been aware of odd situations.
I was sitting on an advisory committee for the governor of Alaska for a short period, and I shouldn't take an advisory committee.
that the University of Alaska had done a thing that the University of California had never allowed to happen.
They took some money from the pipeline company to do an oceanographic survey in the region of Boundies where the tanker port is going to be at the side of the pipeline.
That in itself I have no objection to.
The thing was, however, that they were willing to take with the money
a restriction on the lease of the data to anybody for five years, something like that.
And anybody meant even another part of the Alaskan government.
And they found themselves in a very awkward position when the Alaskan government fisheries groups and so forth started doing physical oceanography.
They had to do the whole thing over again.
They couldn't use the University of Alaska data because of the agreement that had gone with the funding.
That's the kind of thing that can give the whole game a bad name, it seems to me.
Now, I want to return to ONR, if I can, for a second.
In terms of ONR's funding of projects, was it your experience that the things ONR was interested in tended to attract the scientists to it?
Is it the grants themselves, sort of predetermined research?
Let me try that.
I don't think so.
It's always hard to decide.
I guess
I was using some words like basic research and things like that a while ago.
I find those really are not very satisfying terms.
I think in fact that one man's basic research can be another man's applied research.
The doer doesn't have to even have the same evaluation of it as the sponsor does.
And if you run a good institution,
why the idea is to see that the people who are interested in certain kinds of things make contact with sponsors who are interested in those same kinds of investigations.
That's a kind of idealistic picture.
It doesn't really work that way, except perhaps in first order.
But nevertheless, that's the way it ideally should work.
These days, I think that a scientist is faced with enough choices about what to do
that you can't claim that you do a particular experiment just because in some abstract way it was more scientifically interesting.
You're rattled around by your peers in terms of what you're working on, and you're rattled around by the funding agencies in terms of what they're interested in putting money in,
On top of that, you're rattled around by just what kinds of tools you have or what your own capabilities are.
And with all of those, you have a lot of options as to what the next thing is you're going to work on.
And you sort of take a weighted average across all of these different things, and sometimes you'll come up with
pushing pretty hard to work on something where the funding doesn't come very easily.
Well, it may turn out that, in fact, the funding and your own inclination go in the same direction pretty easily.

I think that what you wind up with, of course, is some sort of natural selection in the sense that physical oceanographers that are interested in a particular kind of problem are more likely to be supported by O&R than those that are interested in some other kind of problem.

This is why I'm very much opposed to various congressmen's ideas about having a single agency for supporting the motion of interest and all sorts of things, because if there were only one, then you'd only have this single monolithic thing to deal with, and the kind of research we can do would lose its sort of resiliency and diversity, which now exists because you can do certain things
within our sphere, you can do other things within the NSF sphere, or either of those, like what you want to do, or you can go try your land management, or geological survey, or whatever.
And I think we'll have a healthy community as long as we have this diversity of interests on the part of the users, and I think it's a mistake to try to think you can truthfully take the
the needs of some agency and represent them in some other agency and expect this is going to have any fruitful result.
But if an agency needs to know about the ocean, it needs to have some people working for it who in fact know about the ocean and are trying to learn about the ocean.
And this almost means that even within the Navy, I have regretted some of the moves that they've taken to try to centralize oceanography.
I think that there's a limit to how far you should go in that regard.
You really should leave some of the oceanography scattered out around because it'll be used better.
It's just lying there on the desk next to you.
If you sit in a building where there's oceanography, you're more likely to think about the ocean.
